Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2007 10:13PM CJAY wrote: i guess because i am not sure how bad is too bad, i have just continued with the treatment.  in july i did mention to the onc that i was really having a hard time with the neuropathy and it was the one side effect i hated.  at that time he increased the lyrica and decreased my abraxane slightly.  i do have trouble walking for any length of time.  mostly because it is uncomfortable, not because of balance, although that is a bit of an issue.  walking as exercise is uncomfortable enough that i just dont do it very much at all anymore.  for a year i had absolutely no weight gain.  however in the past two months i have gained about 5 pounds.  i am not real sure why that is.  my onc has not used the term NED but he has said that i am in stable remission.  not sure if that is just another way to state it or not.  hope this helps answer some of your questions.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2007 08:06PM CJAY wrote: hey ladies.  i have been doing A & A (weekly) since last august.  that's right, over a year now.  i have had a few short breaks, none longer than a month.  the absolute greatest news is, IT WORKS!  in april i had my first scan that showed no lesions.  i get scans every 6 weeks, and every one since then has come back exactly the same!  whoo hoo.  i asked the doc, how long do we keep doing this if nothing is showing up on my scans.  he said there is no hard and fast rule about when to stop.  but said if i was stable remission for 6 months we would stop.  that was in august, so i am counting the months, weeks, days until january.  as far as side effects, i definitely have the neuropathy in my hands and feet.  but the doc has me on lyrica for that.  does not go away, but is managable i guess.  nose bleeds, leaky eyes (doc thinks this could be clogged tear ducts which happens with taxanes), general fatigue, and bad nails on my hands and feet.  i keep them painted and have just learned to deal with them.  anyway, just wanted to weigh in.  how long have you guys been on A and A.  onc nurse says they are using avastin with everything now it seems.
